item.title: Help, by Land Lines
item.description:
Help, by Land Lines

Help by Land Lines, released 21 August 2015

item.title: Meet Justin Parker of We Recycle. His outlook on Pueblo's recycling culture is grim despite polls that show Pueblo residents support more recycling efforts. In 2013, We Recycle received a $293,086 grant to fund more recycling projects. But not many are taking advantage of the new resources, according to Parker. "I think the mindset will get worse," he told PULP reporter Ashleigh Hollowell. More on this story at pueblopulp.com. ðŸ“· @karanormal

item.title: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
item.description:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

Meet Justin Parker of We Recycle. His outlook on Pueblo's recycling culture is grim despite polls that show Pueblo residents support more recycling efforts. In 2013, We Recycle received a $293,086 grant to fund more recycling projects. But not many are taking advantage of the new resources, according to Parker. "I think the mindset will get worse," he told PULP reporter Ashleigh Hollowell. More on this story at pueblopulp.com. ðŸ“· @karanormal

item.title: On covering Pueblo's Brain Drain - PULP
item.description:
On covering Pueblo's Brain Drain - PULP

I should have had an inkling that the brain drain was bad long before this year. Maybe when I was on the verge of graduating high school in 2011 and didn't even apply to Colorado State University-Pueblo because I was determined - as were most of my friends - to make Pueblo a part of my past (spoiler, I ended up graduating from CSU-Pueblo this past May).

item.title: The Experts Were Wrong About the Best Places for Better and Cheaper Health Care
item.description:
The Experts Were Wrong About the Best Places for Better and Cheaper Health Care

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. - As part of his push for the Affordable Care Act in 2009, President Obama came to Central High School to laud this community as a model of better, cheaper health care. "You're getting better results while wasting less money," he told the crowd.

item.title: Colorado gold rush ghost town revisited - BBC News
item.description:
Colorado gold rush ghost town revisited - BBC News

At the height of the Colorado gold rush, the city of Victor, high up in the Rocky Mountains, had a population of more than 18,000 people. The gold and the prospectors are now long gone, but the town remains - along with a few hundred residents.

item.title: Southern Colorado From Space
item.description:
Southern Colorado From Space

Have you ever seen Colorado like this? "The Colorado front range at night - Fort Collins, Denver, Colorado Springs and Pueblo shining bright." From astronaut Kjell N. Lindgren onboard the International Space Station on December 5, 2015.
